# Payroll & Public-Sector Lending Intelligence
**Research Date:** 2025-12-03
**Focus:** Payroll lending (check-off systems) for government employees across 11 African markets
**Analyst Note:** This vertical represents a critical opportunity for MFI software due to lower NPLs, guaranteed repayment, and high demand

---

## Executive Summary

### Key Findings

**Market Opportunity:**
- Payroll/public-sector lending is a massive, underserved vertical across Africa
- Government employees number 530,000+ (Kenya), 1.5M (Nigeria), with similar populations across other markets
- Lower NPL rates compared to unsecured lending (payroll NPLs typically 50-70% lower)
- Guaranteed repayment through direct salary deductions reduces default risk
- Growing digitalization of payroll systems (IPPD, IPPIS, CAGD, PERSAL) creates integration opportunities

**Regulatory Landscape:**
- Maximum deduction limits: 33% (Kenya, Nigeria), 25% (South Africa), 40-50% (Ghana, Uganda)
- Interest rate caps vary by country but trend toward consumer protection
- Increasing central bank oversight and licensing requirements for lenders
- Strong push toward digital lending regulation (2024-2025)

**Technology Gap:**
- Most lenders lack real-time payroll integration
- Manual affordability checks create delays and fraud risk
- No unified multi-employer management systems
- Limited loan stacking prevention
- Employer portals are rudimentary or non-existent
- **CRITICAL OPPORTUNITY:** Build payroll system integrations (IPPD, IPPIS, CAGD, PERSAL, IPPS, T-Pay)

**Competitive Landscape:**
- Traditional banks dominate (KCB, Equity, GCB, Fidelity, etc.)
- SACCOs/Cooperatives have strong government employee penetration
- Microfinance banks entering aggressively (2024-2025)
- Fintech disruption beginning (digital lenders, earned wage access)
- Software vendors: Craft Silicon, Titansoft, MFI Expert, Intrepid

---

## KENYA

### Market Overview
- **Market size:** Alternative lending market $374.2M (2024), growing 30.2% annually; check-off lending subset estimated $100-150M
- **Key players:**
  - Banks: KCB (13% interest), Equity Bank, Absa, Faulu Bank, Kingdom Bank (17% interest)
  - SACCOs: NRS DT Sacco, Teachers' SACCOs
  - MFBs: 14 deposit-taking microfinance banks (CBK-licensed)
  - Fintechs: Mwananchi Credit, MyCredit, Premier Kenya
- **Government employees:** 530,000+ civil servants (post-ghost worker cleanup), including teachers, police, healthcare workers
- **Market dynamics:** Teachers Service Commission (TSC) represents largest single employer group; loan tenures extended to 120 months (2024)

### Regulatory Framework
- **Check-off authorization:** Through Integrated Payroll and Personnel Database (IPPD), managed by National Treasury
- **Max deduction:** 66.66% maximum total deductions (two-thirds rule under Employment Act 2007); net take-home must be at least one-third of basic salary. Third-party deductions subject to one-third rule on first-come, first-served basis.
- **Rate cap:** No fixed rate cap currently (interest rate cap repealed 2019); market rates 13-17% for check-off loans; CBK Policy Rate at 9.25% (Oct 2025, down from 12-year high)
- **Recent changes:**
  - Banking (Penalties) Regulations 2025: Max penalties KES 20M (institutions), KES 1M (individuals)
  - Credit-only lenders with KES 20M+ capital require CBK license (2025)
  - 179 MFB licenses revoked (2023) for non-compliance
- **Source:** [Digital Banking News](https://digitalbankingnews.co.ke/salary-advances-in-kenyas-public-sector-vs-private-sector/), [Nasonga Check-off Guide](https://nasonga.com/checkoff-loans-kenya), [IntaSend Deductions](https://intasend.com/payments/salary-deductions-in-kenya)

### NPL & Default Data
- **Payroll loan NPL:** Specific data not available; estimated 3-5% based on check-off structure
- **Unsecured NPL:** 16.4% (Dec 2024, highest in decade); 17.1% (Dec 2024 CBK); increased from 15.6% (Dec 2023)
- **Context:** NPLs rising due to economic pressures, high interest rates (avg 16.89%), drought affecting agriculture (20% NPL in ag sector)
- **Comparison:** Check-off loans significantly outperform unsecured lending due to automatic deduction
- **Source:** [Cliffe Dekker Hofmeyr Kenya NPL Analysis](https://www.cliffedekkerhofmeyr.com/news/publications/2025/Practice/Banking-Finance-Projects/banking-finance-and-projects-alert-3-April-kenyas-rising-bad-loans-a-closer-look), [Kenya Bankers Association](https://www.kba.co.ke)

### Key Employers
| Employer | Employees | Check-off Status | Current Lenders |
|----------|-----------|------------------|----------------|
| Teachers Service Commission (TSC) | ~250,000 | Active (T-Pay system) | KCB, Equity, Absa, Faulu, Kingdom Bank, Teacher SACCOs |
| National Police Service | ~50,000 | Active (IPPD) | KCB, Equity, specialized police SACCOs |
| Ministry of Health | ~80,000 | Active (IPPD) | Multiple banks, health worker SACCOs |
| Kenya Defence Forces | ~24,000 | Active (IPPD) | Limited (security restrictions) |
| County Governments | ~50,000+ | Active (IPPD) | Local banks, SACCOs |
| Civil Service (Ministries) | ~100,000 | Active (IPPD) | Multiple banks, civil service SACCOs |

### Technology Gap
- **T-Pay System:** TSC uses T-Pay for payroll, but integration with lenders is manual
- **IPPD Integration:** No real-time API for lenders; requires MOU with National Treasury
- **Affordability Verification:** Manual payslip review; prone to fraud and delays
- **Loan Stacking:** Limited visibility across lenders; borrowers can over-leverage
- **Employer Portals:** Rudimentary; no self-service for employees
- **Opportunity:** Build IPPD/T-Pay connectors for real-time verification and deduction tracking

---

## NIGERIA

### Market Overview
- **Market size:** Payday/payroll loan sector growing rapidly since 2010; estimated $200-300M (pioneer lenders: Renmoney, Credit Direct, Zedvance, Page International)
- **Key players:**
  - Banks: Access Bank, GTCO, UBA, Zenith Bank, Fidelity Bank
  - MFBs: Octopus MFB (3% rate), Prestige MFB, 729 licensed MFBs (9 national, 121 state, 599 unit-level)
  - Fintechs: Renmoney, Credit Direct, SeamlessHR (earned wage access)
  - Cooperatives: Victory Hands MPCS, Nolt Finance
- **Government employees:** 1.5M federal workers on payroll (2023, up from 720,000 after ghost worker elimination in 2022); 70,000 ghost workers removed
- **Personnel cost:** NGN 5.51 trillion (2024 budget), 61.63% of expenses go to personnel and debt service

### Regulatory Framework
- **Check-off authorization:** Through Integrated Payroll and Personnel Information System (IPPIS) managed by Office of the Accountant General of the Federation (OAGF)
- **Max deduction:** 33.33% maximum (one-third of monthly wages per Labour Act Section 5); IPPIS loans capped at 70% of salary
- **Rate cap:** No fixed cap; CBN Monetary Policy Rate at 27% (Nov 2025, down from 27.5%); commercial lending rates 20-30% for unsecured; MFBs 18-30%; IPPIS loans as low as 3% monthly (36% APR)
- **Recent changes:**
  - Deduction of Tax at Source (Withholding) Regulations 2024 (effective Jan 1, 2025)
  - Digital lending regulations tightening (2024)
  - Minimum wage raised to NGN 75,000/month (May 2024, doubled from NGN 30,000)
- **Source:** [SabiLaw Deductions](https://sabilaw.org/fines-and-deductions-from-a-workers-salary-are-illegal/), [IPPIS Website](https://ippis.gov.ng/), [Nigeria Labour Act](https://lawsofnigeria.placng.org/laws/L1.pdf)

### NPL & Default Data
- **Payroll loan NPL:** Specific data not available; estimated 2-4% based on payroll deduction structure
- **Unsecured NPL:** 3.93% average for major banks (2024, down from 4.18% in 2023); absolute NPL value NGN 1.57 trillion (up 30% from NGN 1.21T in 2023)
- **MFB NPL:** 12.7% Portfolio at Risk (PAR) for MFBs (June 2024) vs 4.1% for commercial banks
- **Sector leaders:** GTCO breached 5% threshold at 5.18%; UBA at 6.64%; Stanbic IBTC 4.18%; Zenith 3.13%; Fidelity 3.22%; Access 3.03%
- **Context:** Rising inflation, naira devaluation driving NPLs higher in absolute terms despite ratio improvements
- **Source:** [Dataphyte NPL Analysis](https://dataphyte.com/latest-reports/is-nigerias-falling-non-performing-loans-a-sign-of-tightening-credit-or-bank-stability/), [Businessday NPL Report](https://businessday.ng/companies/article/non-performing-loans-cross-n1-5trn-despite-improved-loan-quality/)

### Key Employers
| Employer | Employees | Check-off Status | Current Lenders |
|----------|-----------|------------------|----------------|
| Federal Ministries (IPPIS) | ~1.5M total | Active (IPPIS) | Octopus MFB, Prestige MFB, Access, UBA, Zenith |
| Nigerian Police Force (NPF) | ~370,000 | Active (IPPIS) | Octopus MFB (3%), specialized police MFBs |
| Nigeria Customs Service (NCS) | ~25,000 | Active (IPPIS) | Octopus MFB, banks |
| Military/Defence | ~200,000 | Active (IPPIS) | Limited access, specialized MFBs |
| Healthcare Workers | ~150,000+ | Active (IPPIS) | Multiple banks, MFBs |
| Teachers (Federal) | ~500,000+ | Active (IPPIS) | Multiple banks, MFBs, cooperatives |

### Technology Gap
- **IPPIS Integration:** Centralized but integration with lenders is limited; requires OAGF approval
- **REMITA Integration:** Salary payments through REMITA platform; some lenders integrate
- **Verification Delays:** Manual IPPIS number verification; no real-time API
- **Loan Stacking:** High risk due to fragmented lending landscape (729 MFBs + banks + fintechs)
- **Affordability:** 70% salary cap difficult to enforce without centralized tracking
- **Opportunity:** Build IPPIS connectors, REMITA integration, cross-lender loan registry

---

## GHANA

### Market Overview
- **Market size:** Part of West African MSME lending market; specific payroll lending size not disclosed; CAGD payroll covers all government workers
- **Key players:**
  - Banks: GCB Bank (22.75% base rate, lowest in country), Fidelity Bank Ghana, Societe Generale Ghana, Absa Ghana
  - MFBs: Limited data; sector consolidating
  - SACCOs: Strong government worker presence
- **Government employees:** Detailed count not available; estimated 400,000+ based on wage bill data
- **Salary developments:** 23% base pay increase (H1 2024), 25% increase (H2 2024)

### Regulatory Framework
- **Check-off authorization:** Through Controller and Accountant General's Department (CAGD) Mechanized Payroll System; integrated with National ID Authority (NIA) Ghana Card for validation (launched Jan 2024)
- **Max deduction:** 40-50% of net monthly income (financial institution standard for affordability); no fixed statutory limit found
- **Rate cap:** No fixed cap; Bank of Ghana MPR at 18% (Nov 2025, down from 27% in 2024, peak 30% in 2023); GCB base rate 22.75%; market lending rates 20-30%
- **Recent changes:**
  - Ghana Card mandatory for payroll validation (Jan 2024) to eliminate ghost workers
  - Open Banking Directive (Dec 2024 draft) for secure data sharing
  - Consumer protection guidelines (2021 Notice on Abolition of Unfair Fees)
- **Source:** [Bank of Ghana](https://www.bog.gov.gh/), [NIA Ghana Card Integration](https://nia.gov.gh/government-launches-integrated-database-for-payroll-validation-and-verification/), [Loan Affordability Guide](https://www.gesquicknewsseekers.com/2025/02/loan-affordability-calculator-step-by.html)

### NPL & Default Data
- **Payroll loan NPL:** Specific data not available; estimated 2-4% based on CAGD deduction structure
- **Unsecured NPL:** Ghana banking sector data limited in search results; Bank of Ghana strengthening supervision due to historical NPL issues
- **Source:** Data limited; requires direct Bank of Ghana reports

### Key Employers
| Employer | Employees | Check-off Status | Current Lenders |
|----------|-----------|------------------|----------------|
| Ghana Education Service (GES) | ~400,000 teachers | Active (CAGD/T-Pay) | GCB, Fidelity, Societe Generale, SACCOs |
| Civil Service (Ministries) | ~100,000+ | Active (CAGD) | Multiple banks |
